title: AB 2133
content:
The State of California enacts the following. The State of California prioritizes improving occupational health and safety for family child care providers to protect both providers and the children in their care from hazards. Family child care providers face risks such as toxic chemicals, illness, stress, and physical hazards. It is crucial for them to receive training to prevent injuries and illnesses on the job. The director is required to annually publish a list of licensed child day care facilities, excluding small family day care homes, detailing their services and licensed capacity. The department must protect the personal privacy of small family day care homes by preventing the use of lists containing names and addresses. To protect the privacy of small family day care homes, the department will restrict the use of lists containing identifying information, except for necessary licensing purposes and providing information to specific agencies and programs. The department will adopt regulations on the confidentiality of information provided on small family day care homes, ensuring referral only to licensed homes in good standing. Violators may be denied access to information and reported to appropriate departments. Section 1596.864 of the Health and Safety Code defines "family child care provider" as either a licensed family day care home provider or a person providing child care under a publicly funded program. Publicly funded programs include early learning and care subsidies administered by state departments or agencies, excluding the K-12 public education system. Family child care providers must attend a two-hour training on occupational health and safety risks specific to their profession. The State Department of Social Services may establish a schedule for completion within four years or three months of becoming a provider. The training includes identifying and minimizing risks such as chemical hazards, infectious diseases, and physical hazards. The training for family child care providers includes discussions on infectious diseases, physical hazards, and stress. Presentations by relevant organizations are approved by the department to improve the child care system. The Department of Industrial Relations selects an entity to provide the required training based on specific requirements. The training for family child care providers includes discussions on infectious diseases, physical hazards, and stress. An entity selected by the Department of Industrial Relations will develop and approve the curriculum for the training sessions. The State Department of Social Services will administer the contract for the training. Coordination with other preservice training requirements and resource networks will be done to reduce the burden on providers. (g) The department will provide lists of family child care providers attending training to the training entity for updates on health and safety issues. Providers can request to have their personal information removed from the lists. 
(h) The department and training entity must comply with the Dymally-Alatorre Bilingual Services Act, offering training materials in non-English languages. 
(i) This section will be effective on July 1, 2017. Section 1 of the legislation aims to protect the rights of child care providers in alternative payment programs by allowing them to file complaints with the State Department of Education for violations of federal or state laws. The section will be effective on July 1, 2017. Section 8221.6 of the Education Code allows licensed or license-exempt child care providers in alternative payment programs to file complaints if the program violates federal or state laws. The programs covered include the California Alternative Payment Program, CalWORKs Stage 2 Program, CalWORKs Stage 3 Program, and Migrant Alternative Payment Program. This section is dependent on annual budget appropriations or other statutes.
